text: the width is fixed and the height should be as math as the row height
You could set the scaleType of ImageView.

```<ImageView
            android:id="@+id/advertisement_image"
            android:layout_width="128dp"
            android:layout_height="wrap_content"
            android:layout_marginRight="10dp"
            android:visibility="visible"
            android:layout_alignBottom="@+id/row2"
            android:layout_alignParentTop="true"
            android:scaleType="fitXY"
            />```
It’s working now. Thanks <@U04UCB0RU>

Regarding what I posted yesterday about unique identifiers used in both databases and the domain layer. 

In the end I found the best practice for this kind of thing is to not rely to the database for generating the unique id but instead rely on generating it myself, specifically with the use of `UUID.randomUUID()`.
I didn’t know dbs could generate unique ids…
ID PRIMARY KEY UNIQUE AUTO INCREMENT
that’s that innit
How could AUTO INCREMENT be anything but unique
it’s sequential
/gif sql magic
<@U12TR4CJV|bubu> has joined the channel
<@U08GFT5V5>: it's unique because the db has another table which tracks every row that you insert. So it will always insert a new row with id of `LAST_MAX_ROW_NUM + 1`
Interesting
it's a good practice to use it if that id is not used out of the sql queries
I see
Thanks for the explanation

My brain is stuck: I have an Observable that emits multiple `CalendarResponseObject`’s , and one that emits a single `Map<Integer, Type>`. Now I want to zip each of those `CalendarResponseObject` and `Type` into a `new PickupCalendar(calendarResponse, type)` . Does Observable.zip work in thise case?
think zip would take one each, so it’ll just return you a single PickupCalendar
Yes, that is what happened :simple_smile:

text: <@U053PPGDC>: That worked nicely! Thanks
Cool
<@U0QR1SM32>: u can also use `repeatWhen`
and zip both observables
Would that repeat the whole chain? As the map is a result from network request
so u can create an observable for you `Map<Integer, Type>` and attach a repeat when to it
I’ll look into it.. worked exactly the way I wanted it to with `withLatestFrom` , but will experiment abit with both
i create a code snippet in a bit
<@U0QR1SM32>: :ok_hand:

<@U0QR1SM32>: you want an operator similar to `cartesian` from functional languages. You can do this using `map` and `flatmap`.

`mapObservable.flatMap((map) -> calendarResponseObservable.map((calendarResponse) -> new PickupCalendar(map, calendarResponse)));`
Thanks <@U09T8SFG8> that worked too :stuck_out_tongue:
keep in mind though that cartesian product costs a lot in my experience. How many CalendarResponses do you get per second?
on average
Haven’t really timed it, but at most 8 before onComplete
that's nothing then you are fine

text: awesome
<@U12TR4CJV>: never measured, but imo Observable is always the smarter choice - it’s harder to fuck up and better syntax

<@U12TR4CJV> the speed performance is likely faster for an async task just because it runs less code. The true difference though is likely in the nanosecond range and the real performance difference is that RX (assuming you mean RX observables) require many objects to be created. This is typically a non concern since most RX calls are run infrequently such as when the activity resumes or during oncreate, etc.

attachments.title: Handling Runtime Changes | Android Developers
attachments.text: Some device configurations can change during runtime (such as screen orientation, keyboard availability, and language). When such a change occurs, Android restarts the running Activity (onDestroy() is called, followed by onCreate()). The restart behavior…

Android Studio 2.1 Release Candidate is now available in the canary, dev and beta channels.  This build fixes a couple of important bugs reported in beta 3.The main feature in 2.1 is support for Android N preview; other than that, the release is nearly identical to the 2.0 stable release from a couple of weeks ago, but with a few extra bug fixes and some tweaks to Instant Run performance.InstallationYou can update your current 2.0 or 2.1 Preview installation to 2.1 RC via the built-in patch...
